article_title: GOP: It’s no longer playing catch-up to Clinton on tech outreach
article_text:
GOP: It’s no longer playing catch-up to Clinton on tech outreach

Photo: Michael Macor, The Chronicle A Hackathon brought together Sarah Bonk,of San Francisco and Chris...

Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton has been to San Francisco half a dozen times, mostly for private fundraisers. But GOP candidate Jeb Bush easily upstaged her this month with a single campaign visit that skillfully combined an Uber ride and a visit to a South of Market tech firm.

article_metadata.sailthru.author: By Carla Marinucci
article_metadata.description: [...] GOP candidate Jeb Bush easily upstaged her this month with a single campaign visit that skillfully combined an Uber ride and a visit to a South of Market tech firm.  The former secretary of state said that while the “gig” economy “is creating exciting opportunities,” she would “crack down on bosses who exploit employees by misclassifying them as contractors.”  [...] the contrast appears stark, he said, when GOP candidates Bush and Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul have come to the Bay Area for public events that involve the tech community — those moves play better with the Millennial crowd than Clinton’s appearances at pricey, private fundraisers.  Bush isn’t the only 2016 GOP presidential candidate having some appeal in the the tech world and especially Silicon Valley, where Millennial and libertarian voters will be key targets.  Democrats counter that Clinton’s team has been aggressively hiring some of the best tech minds to bulk up her 2016 campaign — including Google’s director of product management for civic innovation and social impact, Stephanie Hannon, to be her team’s chief technology officer.  “Jeb Bush can’t embrace the innovation economy of today while trying to take us back to the health care system of yesterday,” said Eric Walker, a spokesman for the Democratic National Committee, citing Bush’s pledge to end Obamacare.  [...] Dan Siroker, director of analytics on Barack Obama’s 2008 presidential campaign, says he has seen a “huge shift” in the attention paid by both parties to tech since that campaign, when “Republicans missed an opportunity” and had to play catch-up.  Siroker, the founder and CEO of Optimizely — a San Francisco firm that specializes in data analytics to boost Web page effectiveness — says his company is working with clients on both sides of the aisle who are eager to make the most of their tech platforms to maximize their profiles.  Today, “some campaigns are focused on big money, some are focused on traditional fat-cat hotel ballroom events and personal connections — but others are focused on how do we optimize” technology, for both political messaging and sophisticated voter and donor targeting, he said.  “In the coming election cycle, the foundation has been laid” for groundbreaking work, especially since candidates and their teams are increasingly looking at “how they can slice and dice data” and impact traffic — and thereby, the number of voters they reach — across the board, he said.
article_metadata.author.name: By Carla Marinucci
